content.raw:
this is the same question we are grappling with in the pose frame semantics proposal, and we are discussing adding implicit joint frames to the link scope of the parent and child links

* #!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/14/pose-frame-semantics-suggested-semantics/activity#comment-100143077

In this case, we could avoid the namespacing `..` issue if you define both robots in a single model `connected_robots` and included both arms with distinct names into that model. I can write this out if it's not clear.
content.html:
this is the same question we are grappling with in the pose frame semantics proposal, and we are discussing adding implicit joint frames to the link scope of the parent and child links

  • #!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/14/pose-frame-semantics-suggested-semantics/activity#comment-100143077

In this case, we could avoid the namespacing .. issue if you define both robots in a single model connected_robots and included both arms with distinct names into that model. I can write this out if it's not clear.

content.raw: Yeah, could you expand on this? \(if you, uh, still remember?\)
content.html: Yeah, could you expand on this? (if you, uh, still remember?)

content.raw:
I think this example text has changed since I made this comment; it now has `<pose frame="/robot_1/gripper"...` with a leading `/`

I think I was planning to suggest a change in model topology; instead of

~~~
<model name="super_armio_bros">
    <!-- Arm + Electric Flange + Gripper -->
    <model name="robot_1">
        <include file="arm.sdf"/>
        <include file="flange_electric"/>
        <include file="gripper"/>
    </model>
    <!-- Arm + Pneumatic Flange + Gripper
         For fun, attached to end of above arm's gripper. -->
    <model name="robot_2">
        <include file="arm.sdf"/>
        <include file="flange_pneumatic"/>
        <include file="gripper"/>
    </model>
    <joint name="cute_weld">
        <parent>robot_1/gripper</parent>
        <child>robot_2/link</child>
    </joint>
</model>
~~~

I believe the point I was trying to make is that if you make the arms and flanges siblings, then they can reference each other more easily

~~~
<model name="super_armio_bros">
    <!-- Arm + Electric Flange + Gripper -->
    <model name="connected_robots">
        <include file="arm.sdf">
          <name>arm1</name>
        </include>
        <include file="flange_electric"/>
          <name>flange1</name>
        </include>
        <include file="gripper"/>
          <name>gripper1</name>
        </include>
        <include file="arm.sdf">
          <name>arm2</name>
        </include>
        <include file="flange_electric"/>
          <name>flange2</name>
        </include>
        <include file="gripper"/>
          <name>gripper2</name>
        </include>
        <joint name="cute_weld">
            <parent>gripper1/link</parent>
            <child>arm2/link</child>
        </joint>
    </model>
</model>
~~~
content.html:
I think this example text has changed since I made this comment; it now has <pose frame="/robot_1/gripper"... with a leading /

I think I was planning to suggest a change in model topology; instead of

<model name="super_armio_bros">
    <!-- Arm + Electric Flange + Gripper -->
    <model name="robot_1">
        <include file="arm.sdf"/>
        <include file="flange_electric"/>
        <include file="gripper"/>
    </model>
    <!-- Arm + Pneumatic Flange + Gripper
         For fun, attached to end of above arm's gripper. -->
    <model name="robot_2">
        <include file="arm.sdf"/>
        <include file="flange_pneumatic"/>
        <include file="gripper"/>
    </model>
    <joint name="cute_weld">
        <parent>robot_1/gripper</parent>
        <child>robot_2/link</child>
    </joint>
</model>

I believe the point I was trying to make is that if you make the arms and flanges siblings, then they can reference each other more easily

<model name="super_armio_bros">
    <!-- Arm + Electric Flange + Gripper -->
    <model name="connected_robots">
        <include file="arm.sdf">
          <name>arm1</name>
        </include>
        <include file="flange_electric"/>
          <name>flange1</name>
        </include>
        <include file="gripper"/>
          <name>gripper1</name>
        </include>
        <include file="arm.sdf">
          <name>arm2</name>
        </include>
        <include file="flange_electric"/>
          <name>flange2</name>
        </include>
        <include file="gripper"/>
          <name>gripper2</name>
        </include>
        <joint name="cute_weld">
            <parent>gripper1/link</parent>
            <child>arm2/link</child>
        </joint>
    </model>
</model>

content.raw:
Additional discussion, there may be complications with scoping and ambiguity when drilling into links vs. models.

Some potential solutions:

* To only permit drilling / scoping for models \(we do this in Anzu\); can be done by restricting `/` for model nesting, or use another delimiter `::`

    * May still have an issue with nested models... Need to write out edge cases, .e.g nestin `robot_1` with a sibling of the same name
    
* Super-complex shadowing rules \(a la C\+\+ / Python\)
content.html:
Additional discussion, there may be complications with scoping and ambiguity when drilling into links vs. models.

Some potential solutions:

  • To only permit drilling / scoping for models (we do this in Anzu); can be done by restricting / for model nesting, or use another delimiter ::

    • May still have an issue with nested models... Need to write out edge cases, .e.g nestin robot_1 with a sibling of the same name

  • Super-complex shadowing rules (a la C++ / Python)

content.raw:
For the canonical links, we should define the constraints on `//model`:

If we need a canonical link for frame affixturing, then every model should have at least one frame.

Current Pose Frame PR, we should just say that it’s necessary. We should explore alternatives here.

\(namely dictacting the affixed-to link for purely kinematic models\)

(namely dictacting the affixed-to link for purely kinematic models)

content.raw:
Here are some alternatives:

```
/link1  -  simple, but may get confused with absolute scope after models are all composed?
~/link1  -  like ROS nodes, but kinda confusing as it's not a concatentation...
//link1  -  kinda confusing w.r.t. XPath, though
./link1  -  kinda confusing w.r.t. not having relative references...
```

What do y’all think?
content.html:
Here are some alternatives:

/link1  -  simple, but may get confused with absolute scope after models are all composed?
~/link1  -  like ROS nodes, but kinda confusing as it's not a concatentation...
//link1  -  kinda confusing w.r.t. XPath, though
./link1  -  kinda confusing w.r.t. not having relative references...

What do y’all think?

content.raw:
Per f2f, for modularity / “non-viral-ness” of composiiton:

* Could be coupled to how custom tags are defined.
* Would need to have stages of parsing defined to permit referring to semi-opaque models… \(e.g. cross-referencing frames…\)

Example:

Composing a world with SDFormat, but load a MuJoCo / SMURF model that SDFormat doesn’t know how to convert.

  • Could be coupled to how custom tags are defined.
  • Would need to have stages of parsing defined to permit referring to semi-opaque models… (e.g. cross-referencing frames…)

Example:

content.raw:
what do you want to happen when a joint `//joint/parent|child` refers to a frame? will it just follow the attached-to graph to a link and use that link as if it had been directly specified? I think that is pretty tractable.

but if you want do be able to weld two frames together by name in a `<joint>` tag, I think that would override the relationships specified in various `//pose/@relative_to` tags.
content.html:
what do you want to happen when a joint //joint/parent|child refers to a frame? will it just follow the attached-to graph to a link and use that link as if it had been directly specified? I think that is pretty tractable.

but if you want do be able to weld two frames together by name in a <joint> tag, I think that would override the relationships specified in various //pose/@relative_to tags.

content.raw:
Yeah, following the attached-to graph would work.

And I’m not sure if I follow on the welding logic - how would it override the `@relative_to` bits? Each of the upstream parent links would remain in their same pose; welding wouldn’t cause a “snap-to” like behavior. \(That’s what we do in Drake and what I wanted a ways back, but we wanted to avoid that for ease of backwards compatibility.\)
content.html:
Yeah, following the attached-to graph would work.

And I’m not sure if I follow on the welding logic - how would it override the @relative_to bits? Each of the upstream parent links would remain in their same pose; welding wouldn’t cause a “snap-to” like behavior. (That’s what we do in Drake and what I wanted a ways back, but we wanted to avoid that for ease of backwards compatibility.)

content.raw: To follow-up here, the intent is that the weld freezes the two frames in place where they are \(I assume the `//joint/pose` in this case is ignored\); it shouldn’t affect their location, right?
content.html: To follow-up here, the intent is that the weld freezes the two frames in place where they are (I assume the //joint/pose in this case is ignored); it shouldn’t affect their location, right?

content.raw: Right, it shouldn't affect their initial locations. And the `/joint/pose` would just be expressed in the child frame.
content.html: Right, it shouldn't affect their initial locations. And the /joint/pose would just be expressed in the child frame.

content.raw: Can I ask if y’all could check on this facet?
content.html: Can I ask if y’all could check on this facet?

content.raw:
I believe with the current scoping rule, `pose[@relative_to]` can refer to frames in its parent scope. So `//model/link/pose` , `//model/joint/pose`, and `//model/frame/pose` cannot access world frames.

Also, `//frame[@relative_to]` should be `//frame/pose[@relative_to]`

> This may make backwards compatibility hard...

What's the downside of setting `//model/pose` and then creating frames relative to the model frame? Allowing the other `//pose` elements access world frames would probably complicate things.
content.html:
I believe with the current scoping rule, pose[@relative_to] can refer to frames in its parent scope. So //model/link/pose , //model/joint/pose, and //model/frame/pose cannot access world frames.

Also, //frame[@relative_to] should be //frame/pose[@relative_to]

This may make backwards compatibility hard...

What's the downside of setting //model/pose and then creating frames relative to the model frame? Allowing the other //pose elements access world frames would probably complicate things.

content.raw: Sounds good to me! \(constraining the scope, that is\)
content.html: Sounds good to me! (constraining the scope, that is)

content.raw:
From f2f, this current scoping, connected to files, makes it difficult to copy\+paste text.

Maybe it’s better to keep things more relative, e.g. only allowing popping up the stack explicitly. \(keep it the same semantically _and_ syntactically\) Then files can be copied\+pasted.

Alternative is scope anchoring, e.g. a `//scope` container, and controlling it. Caveat is making sure some sort of naming anchor when handling, or merging semantics.
content.html:
From f2f, this current scoping, connected to files, makes it difficult to copy+paste text.

Maybe it’s better to keep things more relative, e.g. only allowing popping up the stack explicitly. (keep it the same semantically and syntactically) Then files can be copied+pasted.

Alternative is scope anchoring, e.g. a //scope container, and controlling it. Caveat is making sure some sort of naming anchor when handling, or merging semantics.

content.raw: I think we should define composition / nesting a bit further here. I think it's about defining components / subsystems independently and assembling them into unique instances of a model. xacro is used extensively for this purpose in ROS with URDF files, and also has features for parameterizing model components and evaluating simple math expressions. While the include tag can currently override the name, pose, and static elements and add plugins, I'm not sure if this proposal plans to address more general forms of parameterization.
content.html: I think we should define composition / nesting a bit further here. I think it's about defining components / subsystems independently and assembling them into unique instances of a model. xacro is used extensively for this purpose in ROS with URDF files, and also has features for parameterizing model components and evaluating simple math expressions. While the include tag can currently override the name, pose, and static elements and add plugins, I'm not sure if this proposal plans to address more general forms of parameterization.

content.raw: This doesn't sound like a compelling justification because it's not obvious to me why it's important. content.html: how do you feel about including a <world> into another world? we could use the approach from addNestedModel by modifying the model names and adjusting their poses

content.raw:
I don’t feel great about it. `/world` seems like a tag that has non-”compositional” properties, like physics engines, etc. I would rather users put pieces to be composed into models \(which can serve the facet of putting pieces together\), and only use worlds for the final glue to simulate. Trying to combine worlds into one sounds sketchy.

At that point, I’d say text processing \(Python scripts, Ruby scripts, or xacro\) would better serve the purpose of sharing properties \(that could potentially collide\).

I would like this proposal to focus on physical composition.

EDIT: Done [3cbfd6154d73](#!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/commits/3cbfd6154d73)
content.html:
I don’t feel great about it. /world seems like a tag that has non-”compositional” properties, like physics engines, etc. I would rather users put pieces to be composed into models (which can serve the facet of putting pieces together), and only use worlds for the final glue to simulate. Trying to combine worlds into one sounds sketchy.

At that point, I’d say text processing (Python scripts, Ruby scripts, or xacro) would better serve the purpose of sharing properties (that could potentially collide).

I would like this proposal to focus on physical composition.

EDIT: Done 3cbfd6154d73

content.raw:
The following scenario was presented as a use-case for including a `<world>`. Suppose there is a `<world>` that consists of a house, with interior floors and other `<models>`. Now, you want to build a street or neighborhood that includes the house. The caveat is that sometimes you'd like to run/test against just the house, and sometimes you'd like to run/test against the whole collection. The ideal scenario would allow a single specification of the house, which could be included in other worlds. 

I agree that including a world is not as clean as including a model, primarily due to other tags.

Here is a list of options, from my perspective:

1. Do nothing, and make an issue for this feature. We can say we are not supporting it right now.
2. Offer some script that would perform the appropriate text processing. The downside here is that a user would have to run this script every time the included world is modified.
3. Support `<world>` inclusion directly, and layout exactly what would be included and how it would be included. This approach could also be saved for future work.


A
content.html:
The following scenario was presented as a use-case for including a <world>. Suppose there is a <world> that consists of a house, with interior floors and other <models>. Now, you want to build a street or neighborhood that includes the house. The caveat is that sometimes you'd like to run/test against just the house, and sometimes you'd like to run/test against the whole collection. The ideal scenario would allow a single specification of the house, which could be included in other worlds.

I agree that including a world is not as clean as including a model, primarily due to other tags.

Here is a list of options, from my perspective:

  1. Do nothing, and make an issue for this feature. We can say we are not supporting it right now.
  2. Offer some script that would perform the appropriate text processing. The downside here is that a user would have to run this script every time the included world is modified.
  3. Support <world> inclusion directly, and layout exactly what would be included and how it would be included. This approach could also be saved for future work.

A

content.raw:
How’s about a 4th option: a different workflow?  
If a user knows they will be composing a house into a neighborhood, they should always do a majority of their composition in models only \(which generally serve that purpose\), and then for simulating whatever level of entities, they just have a rather simple `<world/>` file, and can delegate whatever text processing they want there?

If a house’s illumination properties can only be described in a `<world/>` context, then I’d say the spec is unable to express local properties, and that would need to be fixed, rather than trying to achieve it through odd heuristics of picking and choosing world properties?

The main concern I have with any support of `world` composition \(of other `world`s\) is that it seems entirely achievable with composite models \(I think\), with less options for conflicting redundancy.
content.html:
How’s about a 4th option: a different workflow?
If a user knows they will be composing a house into a neighborhood, they should always do a majority of their composition in models only (which generally serve that purpose), and then for simulating whatever level of entities, they just have a rather simple <world/> file, and can delegate whatever text processing they want there?

If a house’s illumination properties can only be described in a <world/> context, then I’d say the spec is unable to express local properties, and that would need to be fixed, rather than trying to achieve it through odd heuristics of picking and choosing world properties?

The main concern I have with any support of world composition (of other worlds) is that it seems entirely achievable with composite models (I think), with less options for conflicting redundancy.

content.raw:
All that being said, I would love to capture this workflow. For now, I’d prefer to capture it in this design doc, preferably using the model-based workflow.

If we do find that it’s insufficient, and possibly not some form of simple text-processing, then we can create an issue for world composition?
content.html:
All that being said, I would love to capture this workflow. For now, I’d prefer to capture it in this design doc, preferably using the model-based workflow.

If we do find that it’s insufficient, and possibly not some form of simple text-processing, then we can create an issue for world composition?

content.raw: I don't like `model_pose_frame` (each sub-word is its own SDFormat element), how about `placement_frame` (inspired by the title of this section)?
content.html: I don't like model_pose_frame (each sub-word is its own SDFormat element), how about placement_frame (inspired by the title of this section)?

content.raw: and why is this an attribute of include and not an element?
content.html: and why is this an attribute of include and not an element?

content.raw: Sounds good to me on both the name and the element usage. \(It feels kinda odd to make it an element, but I agree that it looks even weirder as an attribute of `//include`.\)
content.html: Sounds good to me on both the name and the element usage. (It feels kinda odd to make it an element, but I agree that it looks even weirder as an attribute of //include.)

content.html: you wouldn't need to use the ^ here if robot_2 was nested inside robot_1

content.raw: going up in scope with `^` feels like it adds a lot of complexity, so I want to make sure we really need to do it
content.html: going up in scope with ^ feels like it adds a lot of complexity, so I want to make sure we really need to do it

content.raw:
Nesting `robot_2` within `robot_1` doesn’t really make sense to me, so I would prefer not to do that here?

That being said, perhaps this could be done better by posturing `robot_2` itself, so that the arm is postured relative to `robot_2`, not `robot_1`. I will try that out.
content.html:
Nesting robot_2 within robot_1 doesn’t really make sense to me, so I would prefer not to do that here?

That being said, perhaps this could be done better by posturing robot_2 itself, so that the arm is postured relative to robot_2, not robot_1. I will try that out.
